justification: The advocacy game was designed to capture the essential ingredient of advocacy goals by assigning participants the role of prosecuting or defending an accused defendant. It was used to measure how advocacy goals influence beliefs about guilt in the face of strong reality constraints.

Participants' probability ratings for patently absurd theories were used to measure whether strong advocacy goals could break reality constraints, demonstrating increased endorsement for these theories when the goal was strong.

measured_by: Manipulation of evidence type (ambiguous vs. unambiguous)
justification: The studies varied the type of evidence (ambiguous vs. unambiguous) to operationalize reality constraints and determine their impact on goal-induced biases. Unambiguous evidence failed to curb biases when participants had strong advocacy goals.

In Study 7, the worst acceptable offer in plea negotiations was used to assess the impact of advocacy goals on practical decision-making, revealing systematic differences in reservation points depending on the strength of the advocacy goal.
